docs.lead_paragraph: Like most groups devoted to curbing the spread of AIDS, the AIDS Resource Center of Wisconsin has spent years promoting condoms. So it was with some surprise that the center received a grant from the Bush administration to persuade teenagers to say no to sex, at least until they are married. ''There won't be any conversation or education about condoms'' in the program, said Mike Gifford, the group's deputy executive director. ''Our message is going to home in, quite substantially, on the fact that the only 100 percent pure way to protect yourself from H.I.V. is to abstain.''
docs.abstract: Pres Bush makes good on campaign pledge and proposes budget for 2003 that would raise federal spending on 'abstinence only' education by $33 million, to $135 million; Bush says abstinence is surest way to prefent unwanted pregnancies and sexually transmitted diseases; with scant research on abstinence-only programs, studies from former Surgeon Gen David Satcher and scientific literature conclude that there is insufficient evidence that abstinence-only programs delay teenage sex; studies suggest combining abstinence message with one that teachers young people how to protect themselves against pregnancy and disease using condom (M)
docs.snippet: Like most groups devoted to curbing the spread of AIDS, the AIDS Resource Center of Wisconsin has spent years promoting condoms. So it was with some surprise that the center received a grant from the Bush administration to persuade teenagers to say...

docs.lead_paragraph: A 30-year-old woman who is very likely to develop a rare form of Alzheimer's disease before she turns 40 has had a baby girl who will be spared that fate because she was genetically screened as an embryo before being implanted in her mother's womb, doctors are reporting. The case is a medical milestone, the first use of genetic testing to prevent an early onset form of Alzheimer's disease. But some find it ethically disturbing because within a few years the mother will probably become unable to take care of her daughter, who will witness her deterioration and death.

headline.main: Baby Spared Mother's Fate By Genetic Tests as Embryo

docs.abstract: 30-year-old woman who is very likely to develop rare form of Alzheimer's disease before she turns 40 has had baby girl who will be spared that fate because she was genetically screened as embryo before being implanted in mother's womb; first such use of genetic testing, reported in AMA Journal, raises ethical questions, since woman will likely not be able to raise child; form of Alzheimer's she has accounts for less than one percent of all cases (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For years, probably decades, the McClure household held a grisly secret that even death could not shake loose. That secret was an infant, perhaps a fetus, whose mummified remains were found on Saturday, according to the police here, inside an old cedar hope chest in the living room of the house where Roberta E. McClure and her sister Dorothy, now both deceased, had lived their entire lives.

headline.main: House Where 2 Sisters Lived Gives Up Its Secret: A Mummified Infant

docs.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
docs.abstract: In this lesson, students learn about a recent Dartmouth study that connected teenagers' movie viewing restrictions with their tobacco and alcohol usage. They then conduct their own research in tobacco and alcohol use among teenagers by devising surveys to be distributed and analyzed in their own school setting.

byline.original: By GEORGIA SCURLETIS and JAVAID KHAN

docs.lead_paragraph: A common practice in treating premature babies is to keep them in darkened rooms -- the better, the thinking goes, to simulate the womb. But researchers from Duke University say in a report in the current issue of Pediatrics they have evidence that exposing some infants to light seems to help them grow faster.

headline.main: Light May Help Premature Babies Grow

docs.abstract: Duke University researchers, in report in current issue of Pediatrics, find evidence that exposing premature babies to light seems to help them grow faster (M)
docs.snippet: A common practice in treating premature babies is to keep them in darkened rooms -- the better, the thinking goes, to simulate the womb.    But researchers from Duke University say in a report in the current issue of Pediatrics they have evidence...

docs.lead_paragraph: The practice of delivering babies has long been influenced by traditions, based on the theories of popular obstetricians rather than on scientific proof. Recently, though, some routine practices have been put through the rigors of scientific testing and have been found ineffective at best and harmful at worst.

headline.main: In Many Delivery Rooms, a Routine Becomes Less Routine

docs.abstract: Article on drastic reduction in episiotomies done in hospital delivery rooms over past 20 years, which have declined to 39 percent in 1998 from 64 percent among women having vaginal deliveries; recent studies show that women who have episiotomy have greater risks of complications, including serious lacerations involving rectum and anal sphincter, than those who do not; photo; graph (M)
docs.snippet: The practice of delivering babies has long been influenced by traditions, based on the theories of popular obstetricians rather than on scientific proof.    Recently, though, some routine practices have been put through the rigors of scientific...

docs.lead_paragraph: Soon after he was born last November at Brigham and Women's Hospital, a baby named Jack was wheeled through a passageway to Children's Hospital, where cardiologists stood by, ready to perform a procedure to open a narrowed valve in his heart. To the doctors' surprise and delight, Jack did not need their help. His aortic valve, though a bit narrow, was wide enough to do its job, and the chambers of his heart looked healthy. Even though he had been delivered six weeks early, he was robust and breathing on his own.

headline.main: Operation on Fetus's Heart Valve Called a 'Science Fiction' Success

docs.abstract: Medical team in Boston corrects deadly heart defect in fetus for first time in United States; surgeons at Brigham and Women's Hospital's Children's Hospital open fetus's pinched aortic valve during 23d week of pregnancy, preventing devastating disorder, hypoplastic left heart syndrome, in which left ventricle stops growing and becomes scarred and useless; untreated, condition is fatal soon after birth; traditional treatment has involved three heart operations, with 30 percent death rate and with many survivors ultimately needing heart transplants; estimated 600 to 1,400 children a year are born in US with this syndrome; diagram showing procedure (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With around eight months to go before the United States Senate election, poll numbers are bound to fluctuate. But a survey released by a Republican pollster last week suggests that Robert G. Torricelli, the Democratic incumbent, may have some work to do to convince voters that he deserves another six years. The poll conducted by National Research Inc. found that just 20 percent of the 646 registered voters surveyed statewide believed that Mr. Torricelli deserves to be re-elected. About 49 percent believed ''it's time to give a new person a chance,'' and 28 percent were undecided. Among Democrats 30 percent said Mr. Torricelli deserved re-election. National Research Inc. is run by Adam Geller who has done work for Republican legislators and congressional candidates.

headline.main: For Senator Torricelli, Poll News Is Bad News

docs.abstract: Republican pollster Adam Geller releases results of poll conducted by National Research Inc showing that only 20 percent of 646 registered voters surveyed statewide believe US Sen Robert Torricelli, Democrat from New Jersey, deserves to be re-elected; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: MIECCIA WEBB is 26 and eight months pregnant with her second child. She lives in Wyandanch and is unemployed and unmarried. When she was pregnant three years ago, she thought about abortion. At the beginning of her second unplanned pregnancy, she thought about abortion again. But after counseling at the Life Center of Long Island in Deer Park, she decided to have her second baby. ''Being there, when you see all the baby stuff, you are pregnant, you go through the feelings,'' she said.

headline.main: Dillon and Spitzer Clash Over Abortion

docs.abstract: Article on clash between Nassau County District Attorney Denis Dillon, Republican and anti-abortionist, and New York State Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, Democrat and abortion rights supporter, over Spitzer's issuing of subpoenas to 11 of 24 crisis pregnancy centers in state, one of which is in Deer Park, Long Island; critics maintain centers misrepresent services they provide and coerce women into not having abortions; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Today is Apologies Day in Rosalind Wiseman's class -- so, naturally, when class lets out, the girls are crying. Not all 12 of them, but a good half. They stand around in the corridor, snuffling quietly but persistently, interrogating one another. ''Why didn't you apologize to me?'' one girl demands. ''Are you stressed right now?'' says another. ''I am so stressed.'' Inside the classroom, which is at the National Cathedral School, a private girls' school in Washington, Wiseman is locked in conversation with one of the sixth graders who has stayed behind to discuss why her newly popular best friend is now scorning her. ''You've got to let her go through this,'' Wiseman instructs. ''You can't make someone be your best friend. And it's gonna be hard for her too, because if she doesn't do what they want her to do, the popular girls are gonna chuck her out, and they're gonna spread rumors about her or tell people stuff she told them.'' The girl's ponytail bobs as she nods and thanks Wiseman, but her expression is baleful.

headline.main: Girls Just Want to Be Mean

docs.abstract: Margaret Talbot article on how adolescent girls mistreat each other; focuses on Rosalind Wiseman and her analysis of girl-on-girl nastiness; notes psychologists are coming to see that girls, though less likely to engage in physical fights, are just as aggressive as boys; girls use social skills to wage complicated battles with other girls aimed at damaging relationships or reputations; photos (L)
